awd_titl_txt: Phase II I/UCRC Colorado School of Mines Site: Center for Advanced Non-Ferrous Structural Alloys (CANFSA)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Advanced Non-Ferrous Structural Alloys (CANFSA) at the Colorado School of Mines (CSM) consists of students, post-docs and faculty who work with their CANFSA counterparts at Iowa State University (ISU) to engage with scientists and engineers from both industry and government laboratories in research on the fundamentals of the physical and mechanical metallurgy of non-ferrous alloys (i.e., alloying and processing effects on microstructure, properties and performance). The motivation for CANFSA is to address the national decline in the training of students in this area that is critical to U.S. dominance in high performance materials, structures and advanced manufacturing. Today, there are only a few universities remaining who train students in these core science and engineering areas that are so critical to our industries, especially as National investments are made in new advanced materials and manufacturing strategies. In fact, these declines have greatly reduced; the synergies that existed previously between faculty, students, and the relevant industries, and this, in turn, significantly weakened the technical dominance of US industries that rely heavily  on these materials. CANFSA was organized to counter this trend by conducting fundamental scientific studies on these advanced materials and their manufacturing, thereby filling this critical workforce development gap and simultaneously
contributing to U.S. global industrial competitiveness.

The objective of CANFSA is to conduct critical basic and applied physical metallurgy;research of direct relevance to the industries that develop, manufacture and use advanced  non-ferrous structural alloys, and to train students in these important subjects. This is accomplished by engaging students in topics of importance to industry and government labs, and to have both faculty members and external mentors guide the students' fundamental research. The specific details of the projects that are conducted within the Center vary as topics are selected that have the most direct relevance for the partners from industry and the national laboratories. To date, the Center has conducted leading research in the areas of: thermal and mechanical processing of non-ferrous alloys (e.g., 3rd Generation Al-Li alloys, texture anisotropy of Ti-6Al-4V); ultrafine grained alloys and their mechanical behavior (e.g., Ti and Mg); aging of high-strength beta-Ti alloys; processing of microeutectic Al alloys; microstructural evolution (e.g., Ni-Ti-Hf intermetallics, Ni-based superalloys, high entropy alloys); multi-layer coatings; lube-free die casting; and the role of trace elements and small microstructural variations on mechanical properties. To conduct these varied research projects and accomplish the goals of the Center, faculty members with complementary ;expertise in the areas of theory, modeling, processing and characterization are working together with members from industry and government laboratories. Mines has a variety of state-of-the-art processing and characterization tools that students, post-docs, and faculty use to address complex, yet precompetitive, projects that are of interest to a number of the our member companies. The expertise at Mines is complementary to that at ISU and, collectively, CANFSA is able to offer unique capabilities to its membership.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Advanced Non-Ferrous Structural Alloys (CANFSA), a National Science Foundation (NSF) Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) at the Colorado School of Mines (Mines) and Iowa State University (ISU), was established in 2011. CANFSA is the only research center at a US university dedicated to non-ferrous physical metallurgy at the intersection of suppliers, makers, and users of non-ferrous alloys. CANFSA's mission is to generate and apply new non-ferrous physical metallurgy knowledge by bringing together university, government, and industry stakeholders to solve challenging problems through pre-competitive research, support faculty, and build a pipeline of students trained in areas of strategic importance to the US manufacturing base, the US Department of Energy (DOE), and the US Department of Defense (DoD). CANFSA's vision is to be the premier industry-university center for non-ferrous physical metallurgy. Specifically, we seek to: (1) investigate industrially relevant processing-microstructure-property-performance relationships with state-of-the-art experimentation and modeling (2) connect academia, government, and industry, (3) train students and the next generation of non-ferrous physical metallurgists; and (4) support students, faculty and curricula in physical metallurgy. CANFSA enables lower cost, yet high quality research and development in a university setting, when compared to government agencies and industry, and provides a forum for the dissemination of research and facilitates dialogue between suppliers, makers, and users of non-ferrous alloys.

 

The physical metallurgy, processing and use of non-ferrous alloys is extremely diverse, often culminating in advanced materials that must exhibit performance in extreme environments. Example metallic alloys included in the non-ferrous designation are lightweight alloys, such as aluminum (Al), magnesium (Mg), and titanium (Ti), high temperature alloys such as nickel (Ni) and refractory alloys (e.g., niobium (Nb)), and unique alloys such as multi-principal element alloys (MPEAs) and shape memory alloys (SMAs). Example processes used to create non-ferrous alloys include casting, additive manufacturing (i.e., three-dimensional (3D) layer-by-layer printing), wrought (thermomechanical) processing and severe plastic deformation. There are less than six university departments in the US with metallurgy or metallurgical engineering in their name. Consequently, over the past 20+ years there has been a dramatic decrease in the number of students being properly trained in the physical metallurgy of non-ferrous alloys, and the companies and government agencies that make and/or use them fear the US is losing its dominance. CANFSA is the only university-led consortium meeting this need. CANFSA is establishing and maintaining interactions with the non-ferrous community, recruiting and training top-quality students to perform the center's research activities, and engaging faculty at Mines and ISU to be the premier industry-university center for non-ferrous physical metallurgy. The success of CANFSA builds upon the legacies of Mines and ISU in performing use-inspired metals research and training the next generation of physical metallurgists. CANFSA uniquely brings together university, government, and industry stakeholders, leveraging the resources and capabilities of Mines and ISU.

 

CANFSA research has generated over 30 MS theses and PhD dissertations, and more than 150 peer-reviewed journal or conference manuscripts since its inception. Many CANFSA projects have had impact on industrial practice and processing, and these outcomes represent how CANFSA programs achieve both scientifically rigorous and industrially applicable outcomes from PhD and MS programs. CANFSA also trains the next generation of non-ferrous physical metallurgists with the knowledge, skills, and abilities needed to ensure a vibrant, competitive US supply chain and manufacturing base and for the US DOE and DoD. CANFSA engages undergraduates through NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and internal university programs, and graduate students and postdocs through consortium projects and federal grants; we have recruited students from over 30 universities across the US and internationally to create a talented and diverse workforce for US manufacturing. Many CANFSA students maintain collaborations and work directly with CANFSA through grants or company memberships after completing their degree programs. There is a strong record of workforce development for the non-ferrous industries and relevant national laboratories, and several students are now faculty at universities performing non-ferrous physical metallurgy research, further expanding the impact on the non-ferrous metallurgy field. CANFSA is helping to increase our national manufacturing competitiveness and improving national security by creating the new workforce and knowledge needed for faster product and process developments that will enable US manufacturers to bring emerging products to market sooner. 


Last Modified: 10/02/2022
Modified by: Kester Clarke
